title: Wedgwood Rock
text:
Wedgwood Rock is a <a href="glacial%20erratic">glacial erratic</a> (known to <a href="geologist">geologist</a>s as the Wedgwood Erratic) near the neighborhood of <a href="Wedgwood%2C%20Seattle">Wedgwood</a> in <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a>. Its mineral composition matches that of <a href="Mount%20Erie%20%28Washington%29">Mount Erie</a>, on <a href="Fidalgo%20Island">Fidalgo Island</a> in <a href="Skagit%20County%2C%20Washington">Skagit County, Washington</a>, north. Prior to the establishment of the Wedgwood neighborhood, the erratic was known first as Lone Rock and later simply as Big Rock. Transported to its site by the Puget Lobe of the <a href="Cordilleran%20Ice%20Sheet">Cordilleran Ice Sheet</a> during the <a href="Vashon%20Glaciation">Vashon Glaciation</a> more than 14,000 years ago, it was a landmark for <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a> in what was once a dense <a href="forest">forest</a>.
Today, the rock sits in a residential neighborhood on 28th Avenue NE, near NE 72nd Street, still surrounded by <a href="tree">tree</a>s and brush, and kept clear by local residents.
19th century.
In 1881, the rock, known at the time as Lone Rock, was part of the 160-acre farm of William Weedin. An anonymous 1881 letter to the Seattle "<a href="Seattle%20Post-Intelligencer">Daily Intelligencer</a>" about a <a href="Independence%20Day%20%28United%20States%29">Fourth of July</a> picnic at the rock described it as "in a dense forest" on Weedin's land, and as "a single rock in circumference and in height, rather oval-shaped, covered with a solid network of <a href="moss">moss</a> and interspersed with <a href="liquorice">liquorice</a>, with its graceful fern-shaped foliage hanging in festoons around it." This rock has an estimated mass of 700 metric tons.
In 1888 the Weedin property passed to Mary Miller, widow of William Miller. William Miller, an ally of Territorial Governor <a href="Isaac%20Stevens">Isaac Stevens</a>, fought in the <a href="Puget%20Sound%20War">Puget Sound War</a> and <a href="Yakima%20War">Yakima War</a> of 1856–1857.
20th century and later.
By the early 20th century, the rock was known as Big Rock. With the Miller family's permission, members of Seattle's <a href="The%20Mountaineers%20%28club%29">Mountaineers Club</a> practiced their <a href="rock%20climbing">rock climbing</a> techniques there. <a href="Edmond%20S.%20Meany">Edmond S. Meany</a>, president of Mountaineers and a professor at the nearby <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> brought his students to the rock to learn about glacial movement and land forms. Later, <a href="Boy%20Scouts%20of%20America">Boy Scouts</a> also learned to climb there, taught by German-born climber and scout leader <a href="Wolf%20Bauer%20%28climber%29">Wolf Bauer</a>. <a href="Recreational%20Equipment%20Incorporated">REI</a> founder Lloyd Anderson taught Mountaineers and Boy Scouts at the rock. Among the prominent climbers whose training started at Big Rock were German-born <a href="Fred%20Beckey">Fred Beckey</a> and <a href="Jim%20Whittaker">Jim Whittaker</a>, who became the first American to reach the top of <a href="Mount%20Everest">Mount Everest</a>.
Mary Miller's son Winlock Miller, a member of the U.W. Board of Regents and a promoter of <a href="Mount%20Rainier%20National%20Park">Mount Rainier National Park</a>, kept the land around the rock undeveloped into the 1940s. He sold in the 1940s to developer Albert Balch, who promised Miller that the area immediately around the rock would be preserved as a park, but failed to keep the promise. In 1946, a citizens group tried and failed to convince the <a href="Seattle%20City%20Council">Seattle City Council</a> to preserve the area as a park against landowner Balch's wishes. 
Although surrounded by houses, the rock remained a destination for picnickers, university students, climbers, and, in the 1960s, hippies. In reaction to the last and their perceived drug use, the Seattle City Council passed an ordinance in 1970 making it a crime to climb the rock, punishable by a fine up to $100.
